Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, ones about the walking dead were probably the second most popular horror sub-genre in modern times. The success of George A. Romero’s first entry into that particular camp called ‘Night Of The Living Dead’ spawned nine additional movies, as well as several popular theatrical sequels by other filmmakers. Olivier Assayas' film stars Asia Argento as a woman who had a relationship with Michael Madsen. Madsen is a business man who buys and sells sex in pairs: premium hookers and no-good D-list celebrities – the kind that pay an escort far more than going on limo runs around the city. Things get nasty when one of his friends has a client overdose, allegedly, on drugs tainted with AIDS.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive in today's turbulent economy. In the end, Jerry MEA Culpa falls off a building trying to prove his super-sized ego. Meanwhile, Tom picks up stray kittens in order to get out of unemployment line - only two feet tall cuties should be free food!

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie was decent produced though.
Definitely not worth to watch.

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy fliers have long since left Planet Earth, for adventures in the countless empires that make up the Galaxy beyond. Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity ; It borrows many characteristics and themes from Asian and American cinema alike, while substituting thick, delicious Texan accents with those of epileptic convulsions.
